title: Grouping Fonts into Families
content:
Hi!

Do any of you fine folks know of software that allows you to group stray fonts into families at will? For instance, my office has a mangled list of about 33 Times New Roman versions strewn throughout our font list. I would like to somehow wrangle them together so that my design team is not searching all day for the condensed version etc.

We use both Mac and PC. I am hoping for a solution that suits both systems (hahaha) but I will of course settle for either.

Thanks! Let me know what you know!
author: West

comments.content:
I use Linotype FontExplorer X

There is an option to group families, and it does it for you. It's my favorite font program – and it's free.

[http://www.linotype.com/2631/freedownload.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150308183610/http:/www.linotype.com/2631/freedownload.html "http://www.linotype.com/2631/freedownload.html")

I actually use that on my Mac. I know it would organize the fonts into groups in the program itself. But are you saying there is a function that will group the fonts together for use in other programs?

Basically, I want to be able to scroll down my font list in illustrator/Indesign, and only have: "Helvetica" with all the different helvetica related typefaces contained therein. Does this make sense?

If FontExplorer X can do that, can you tell me how?

This is not a feature of FontExplorer X. It requires something that would actually edit the fonts.

T

FontLab would do it, but....

- way too expensive for the task

- most font licenses don't allow modifications like this

Cheers,

T

Ah. That makes sense that it would be a licensing issue. I hadn't thought of it that way.

Thanks.
